text: hello everyone
my name is raluca and i'm a security
professor at uc berkeley
today i'm going to tell you about our
efforts on a secure collaborative
learning
platform the problem we are addressing
recurs often in society there are many
cases when
organizations wish to learn from the
data
across different organizations yet they
cannot share data with each other
because this data is sensitive
let me give you one example but there
are many examples
banks want to detect money laundering
however criminals
hide their traces across different banks
so if a bank looks
only at its own transaction data they
won't be able to catch many of these
criminals
that's why the banks want to learn from
the data across
different banks but the banks cannot
share data with each other because
they're in competition so they won't
share customer transaction data
and this is a real situation for example
the chief risk officer of scotiabank and
we are collaborating with the scotiabank
says that collaboration will be vital
the ability to put together our data
sets and collaborate on topologies of
attack
through the use of both advanced
encryption and
analytics methods will enhance yields
by orders of magnitude and here's
referring to how much
money laundering they can catch
and besides this there's many other use
cases for example in the financial
sector
one can use financial forensics to
detect human trafficking and sex
trafficking or fraud also in the medical
sector before the pandemic we were
talking to kaiser about using
collaborative learning for flu
prediction models so that's quite an
irony
and this is also useful for nuclear
facility auditing when there's sensitive
data involved
or cloud-based video analytics for homes
or census and whatnot
this is why my students and i have been
building the mcsquared platform
for secure collaborative learning
mcsquared stands for
multi-party collaboration and
competition
and it embodies the principle of sharing
without
showing the data mc squared is an open
source
effort that i'm leading in the rise lab
at the high level in mcsquart what we're
building
is efficient secure collaborative
computation
for everyone and for
everyone what i mean is that there's all
these
many use cases that i mentioned that
could benefit from secure collaborative
learning
but the people who would like to deploy
this kind of use cases could be data
scientists or you know
systems people but not necessarily
security or cryptography experts
so we would like to empower them with a
platform that is easy
to use even without security expertise
so in emphasis squared we expose a
python dsl
that anyone can use to write their
computing task in it
with no expertise of security or
cryptography
now our python dsl also captures
policies and what i mean by policies
are things such as when can we release a
model maybe
only when it's good enough when it helps
every single party not just one party
or privacy policies such as how much
data does the model contain
about my data how much is it leaking and
things like this
so it's possible using mc squared to set
up an end-to-end policy
on data privacy on auditing
accountability and things like this
now to actually enable the secure
computation over sensitive data
and to enable it in an efficient way we
are using
two technologies in mc squared
these are two different technologies
that have a trade-off between them
and one is better than the other
depending on the use case at hand
so one is secure multi-party computation
or mpc and the other is hardware
enclaves
so let me tell you a little bit at a
high level about each one of them
so npc is entirely based on cryptography
so it's a software-based solution
in npc you have n parties that have
sensitive data they are not willing to
share with each other
but they want to train or learn a
function f
or one function f over all their data
and learn the result of the function f
they jointly want to know that result
but in the process they don't want to
share their data with each other
so no party should learn anything
about the data of each other of another
party
other than the function result and this
is exactly what
mpc enables essentially what happens
is that the parties encrypt their data
they share it encrypted so the other
parties can decrypt it they can't see
what it is
but then parties compute on each other's
data in
encrypted form without decrypting it
through the power of cryptography
and then they obtain a computation
result that's encrypted
and they jointly decrypt it so
throughout this whole process
the part is exchanged to only encrypted
data
that they cannot decrypt and they
learned only the final function result
and nothing else about each other
parties data
now the other approach to secure
computation is
via specialized hardware such as
hardware enclaves
hardware enclaves for example intelhd x
keystone mi6 nitron clips
they offer a hard reinforced isolated
execution environment
that protects even against an attacker
that has
root access on a machine
the way they work is that essentially on
the die
on the processor there's this memory
encryption engine me
that encrypts all the data that goes
out of the die into main memory and
eclipse data coming in
so in on the memory you only have
encrypted data so even if an attacker
has root access to the machine they can
only see
an encrypted memory
now these two approaches are separate
and they have a trade-off mpc
is tends to be slow and expensive for
complex computation or big data
and it also requires a cluster
computation at
each organization on the other hand
hardware run clips don't have these
downsides
but they require trusted hardware which
brings
trust assumptions on the hardware vendor
as well as a specialized setup but now
when it comes to the setup we have
cloud such as azure confidential
computing that offer hardware enclaves
or right now even google and amazon are
about to offer
clouds with enclaves but enclaves suffer
from side channel attacks
and the cryptographic solution of npc
doesn't have
so there's a trade-off between the two
of them and the right one to use depends
a lot on the use case
and we've worked with a number of
industry collaborators and we've seen
that
you know each one of the approaches is
better than the other
in different use cases
my students and i in nc squared we have
contributed to both of these directions
and we provide
systems that can do collaborative
learning in both of these
using both of these technologies our
contributions are
aimed at reducing the downsides of these
two technologies
while keeping their benefits so for
example
in the case of npc we have developed
efficient protocols
that can do cnn inference in the case of
delphi
linear models training in the case of
helen
general analytics or ml in the case of
senate
or classical ml inference in the case of
both the dao
for hardware enclaves we have targeted
side channels
namely protecting a large class of side
channels
by designing oblivious algorithms
for example visor is for ml inference
ocq for distribute analytics obliques
for multi-user search opaque for
analytics and
we also have work for general programs
such as civic m
and members
so we have put together our projects
into creating our mc squared platform
which is on the source
at the moment mc squared is not on ray
but there's
an effort in our group for porting a
part of these
projects on race that one can also do
collaborative
training in a secure way on ray
mcsquared already has some adoption for
example
ibm has used opaque which is a part of
mc squared for
two medical use cases eric's son for
a telecom use case and financial alibaba
for
financial oriented use cases and
microsoft and scotiabank
are in a partnership with us for the
anti-money laundering use case
that i mentioned at the beginning of the
presentation and this is really just the
beginning one c squared
because there's so many other possible
places
where m c squared could enable secure
collaborative learning
so to conclude our goal with mc squared
is to enable efficient secure
collaborative computation
for everyone thank you
